message.content:
We need to “roll‐up” (aggregate) only those transactions that affect the income statement. Typically we ignore balance–sheet activities (“Initial”, “Fixed Assets”, “Purchase”, “Transfer”) and then treat the “Expense” items as deductions, add any “Interest Receivables” (which are income) and use the “Sale” transactions’ reported profit (which is computed as sale net – cost). (Other types such as “Depreciation” also are “expenses”.)

One way to “simulate” the process is as follows. (Note that the full table has 117 rows; here is one way to “trace” the calculation.)

Step 1. Ignore rows that do not affect the income statement. That is, omit rows with type “Initial”, “Purchase”, “Fixed Assets”, “Transfer.”

Step 2. For the remaining rows, for each row we do:
– For “Sale” rows we take the “profit” column (which is revenue less cost, already computed) and add it.
– For “Expense”, “Depreciation” and (if “Financial Expenses” appear) we subtract their “amount.”
– For “Interest Receivables” we add the “amount” because these represent interest income.

When you go row‐by–row (see the step–by–step “running‐sum” we show below) the following happens:

Thus the “Profit Before Tax” coming from this complete set of transactions is about 1,131,139.32.

Keep in mind that our “step‐by‐step” running total is an illustration; one must select only the income–statement affecting items and then add (for revenues) and subtract (for expenses) the corresponding amounts.
